text: Trans World Airlines Flight 800 (TWA 800) was a scheduled flight from John F. Kennedy International Airport to Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport on July 17, 1996. The aircraft was a Boeing 747-100 carrying 212 passengers and 18 crew members.James Sanders, The Downing of TWA Flight 800 (New York: EPinnacle, 2013), p. 15 The plane exploded just 12 minutes after takeoff, tore apart and crashed into the Atlantic Ocean near East Moriches, New York. There were no survivors. The cause was determined to be a spark that ignited the center wing fuel tank. It remains the third-deadliest aviation accident in U.S. history. It is one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Boeing 747 in history. ==Passengers and Crew== Nationality Passengers Crew Total 125 17 142 42 0 42 10 0 10 9 0 9 8 1 9 7 0 7 7 0 7 6 0 6 4 0 4 4 0 4 3 0 3 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 0 2 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 Total 212 18 230 Most of the 230 occupants on- board were from the United States, but 42 more came from France, 10 from Argentina, and 60 more from sixteen other countries. The pilots on board TWA Flight 800 were Captain Ralph G. Kevorkian, Co-pilot Steven E. Snyder and Flight Engineer Richard G. Campbell. All had more than 30 years employment with Trans World Airlines. There was also a Flight Engineer Trainee on board Oliver Krick, who was starting the sixth leg of his initial operating experience training. == References == == Other websites == * The Crash of TWA Flight 800; YouTube Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in the United States Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in the 1990s Category:1996 in New York (state) Category:Conspiracy theories Category:July 1996 events
title: TWA Flight 800
